15_1PvAyLAB5H1JKbiFjx95ZJXrNJVyWxs5Hf.body:
Yes. Hyperboria is somewhat different from the rest because they're attempting to decentralize the hardware and software layers of the internet by experimenting with ways of building mesh-nets which rely less on centralized, monopolistic, ISP's . Overall, I think it will be interesting if they figure out how to create global and, what might eventually become, planetary internet infrastructures without undersea cables or deep-space  cabling. I also think fabricating more mesh-net parts would make make scaling each mesh less difficult overtime assuming machines like 3d printers eventually become fast, then cheap, enough to do so.

>[kahpecuce](#comment_19_1MmPY9fniJwwhP6WsgH4jWoq5rBAVV6KWy): if I understand correctly Hyperboria is totally different alternative, trying to achieve just another internet on the long run, through a mesh. So that makes it different, no?

> [pycole](#comment_17_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH): They're very much like Zeronet--but closed source, browser-dependent, and without support for dynamic content. And yet despite being so shitty, they are the closest thing to a direct competitor on this whole list.

Yep, between those two Znet is the clear winner thus far especially since it has managed to do so much more with less funding. This why Maelstrom would probably be better off if they began open sourcing more of it over the long term.
I personally think that the way block-chains are used in tandem with other decentralizing technologies will create more innovation than just block-chains by themselves.

14_1PvAyLAB5H1JKbiFjx95ZJXrNJVyWxs5Hf.body:
> [kasthuri](#comment_12_1BBKD8mSqtGDaK5GQ5Q6A6mLhpc8xrgW97): hiii what is the difference between zeronet and freenet

From what I know.

[Freenet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freenet) 
-Sites can't be deleted
-No javascript
-Takes a few minuets to sync
-Loads faster if left on for a while
-Higher learning curve
-Most secure when peering with friends rather than strangers
-Best for anyone who lives in heavily censored countries

[Zeronet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeronet)
-Websites can be deleted
-Mostly javascript sites so far
-Syncs up immediately
-Cleaner interface
-Faster load load times, especially for popular websites
-Security through Tor network
-Less emphasis on selective peering

> [ha](#comment_1_1BDTDgpyizvUDsc1hcL1pjCvXCy4ozzSFN): I have not seen a single ZeroNet site that uses Java. I think you meant JavaScript.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Javascript#JavaScript_and_JavaA common misconception is that JavaScript is similar or closely related to Java. It is true that both have a C-like syntax (the C language being their most immediate common ancestor language). They also are both typically sandboxed (when used inside a browser), and JavaScript was designed with Java's syntax and standard library in mind. In particular, all Java keywords were reserved in original JavaScript, JavaScript's standard library follows Java's naming conventions, and JavaScript's Math and Date objects are based on classes from Java 1.0,[123] but the similarities end there.
> The differences between the two languages are more prominent than their similarities. Java has static typing, while JavaScript's typing is dynamic. Java is loaded from compiled bytecode, while JavaScript is loaded as human-readable source code. Java's objects are class-based, while JavaScript's are prototype-based. Finally, Java did not support functional programming until Java 8, while JavaScript has done so from the beginning, being influenced by Scheme.

Thanks. Just fixed it.

- Automated Search Engine
- More Video Tutorials
- Works without manual port forwarding
